revision.text:
{{Infobox military structure |name=Cowley Barracks |image=Cowley Barracks.jpg |caption = Cowley Barracks showing the original keep |type = Barracks |map_type = Oxfordshire |pushpin_map_caption = Location within Oxfordshire |location = [[Oxford]] |latitude = 51.74184 |longitude = -1.20243 |coordinates = {{Coord|51.74184 |N|1.20243|W|region:GB_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |ownership = [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defence]] |operator = {{army|United Kingdom}} |built = 1876 |used=1876-1959 |architect = |built_for = [[War Office]] |garrison = |occupants = [[Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire Light Infantry]] }} '''Cowley Barracks''' (originally '''Bullingdon Barracks''') was a military installation in [[Oxford]], England.
==History== The barracks were built in the [[Gothic Revival architecture|Fortress Gothic Revival Style]] at Bullingdon Green using Charlbury stone<ref>{{cite web|title=Parishes: Cowley, A History of the County of Oxford: Volume 5: Bullingdon hundred |year=1957|page= 76-96|url= http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=101882|accessdate=8 November 2014}}</ref> and completed in spring 1876.<ref name=barracks>{{cite web|url=http://www.headington.org.uk/history/war/general/barracks.html|title=Cowley Barracks|publisher=Headington at War|accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> Their creation took place as part of the [[Cardwell Reforms]] which encouraged the localisation of British military forces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/defence/9383385/Echoes-of-the-past-in-these-Army-cuts.html|title=Echoes of the past in these Army cuts|date=8 July 2012| accessdate= 13 November 2014}}</ref> The barracks became the [[Regimental depot|depot]] for the [[52nd (Oxfordshire) Regiment of Foot]] and the [[85th Regiment of Foot (Bucks Volunteers)]].<ref name=training>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060210172841/http://www.regiments.org/regiments/uk/depot/1873.htm|title=Training Depots|publisher=Regiments.org|accessdate=16 October 2016}}</ref> Following the [[Childers Reforms]], the [[43rd (Monmouthshire) Regiment of Foot|43rd (Monmouthshire) Regiment of Foot (Light Infantry)]] and the 52nd (Oxfordshire) Regiment of Foot amalgamated to form the [[Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire Light Infantry|Oxfordshire Light Infantry]] with its depot at the barracks in 1881.<ref name=training/>
Following the [[Haldane Reforms]] the Oxfordshire Light Infantry became the [[Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire Light Infantry]] in 1908. Many recruits enlisted at the barracks during the early stages of the [[World War I|First World War]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lifestoriesandmemories.co.uk/24/2/story/Ben-Reeve.asp|title=Ben Reeve|publisher=Life stories and memories|accessdate=8 November 2014}}</ref>
The original proposal for the [[Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire Light Infantry War Memorial]] was to site it outside the barracks but no suitable site could be found and it was built on Rose Hill instead.<ref name="NHLE">{{National Heritage List for England |num=1369419|desc=Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire Light Infantry War Memorial|accessdate=20 August 2016}}</ref>
The Oxfordshire & Buckinghamshire Light Infantry Museum was established at the barracks in 1925<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rgjmuseum.co.uk/about_history.asp|title=About the history of the museum|publisher=The Royal Green Jackets museum|accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> and during the [[World War II|Second World War]] the barracks were used as a base for the [[Home Guard (United Kingdom)|Home Guard]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/news/11264113.All_quiet_on_the_home_front/|title=All quiet on the home front|publisher=The Telegraph and Argus|date=9 June 2014|accessdate=8 November 2014}}</ref>
The Oxfordshire & Buckinghamshire Light Infantry left the barracks in 1959 and, although the men's quarters were retained, the keep was subsequently demolished.<ref name=barracks/> The museum collection moved from Cowley Barracks to the Slade Park Territorial Army base at that time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.witneygazette.co.uk/news/wgheadlines/features/11274991.New_museum_honours_county___s_Army_history/|title=New museum honours countyâ€™s Army history|publisher=Witney Gazette|date=13 June 2014|accessdate=8 November 2014}}</ref>
Between 1980 and 1992 the national headquarters of the [[United Kingdom Warning and Monitoring Organisation]] was located on the site. Co-located with this organisation was the Headquarters of No 3 Oxford Group [[Royal Observer Corps]]. The site now belongs to [[Oxford Brookes University]] who have built student accommodation on the site.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.subbrit.org.uk/rsg/sites/o/oxford/index.html|title=Oxford: ROC Group HQ No 3|publisher= Subterranea Britannica|accessdate=8 November 2014}}</ref>
